entry.title: Re: IDOC SHPMNT05 DEL not possible because HUs and delive...
entry.content:
IDOC_INPUT_SHPMNT - Yes, this is a standard SAP function module used for inbound processing of shipment IDocs (type SHPMNT05).
SD_SHIPMENT_DELIVERY_DELETE - may be you can try with WS_DELIVERY_UPDATE

The other easiest way to find out the available FMs is go to SE84, to search by:

  • Function group (e.g., V51E, LE_SHP_DELIVERY_PROC)
  • Class (e.g., CL_DELIVERY_PROCESSING)
  • Enhancement spot (e.g., ES_SHP_DELIVERY_UPDATE)

This gives you a broader view of what's available in your release.

entry.title: Re: De-provisioning in SAP analytics cloud from GRC AC vi...
entry.content:
Hello @Abhinay_Nampally 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, the balance confirmation application object FIN_FO_BLNC_CNFRM might be active but not visible in the Output Parameter Determination app due to application or authorisation restrictions.

To properly manage balance confirmation output parameters, please utilise dedicated apps such as Manage Balance Confirmations and Configure Balance Confirmation Output Types.

Make sure the balance confirmation scenario is included in your scope and that your user roles have the necessary authorisations.

For comprehensive guidance, please consult the official SAP documentation.
Balance Confirmation - Output Management Configuration

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

Hi @Joe0603 

I see. Looks like there are some custom calculations that enforce those values of 0. 50, 100, 200. 

You may need to engage with an SAP Partner since it will require to evaluate the requirement and how could be done it differently.  If those values should be different based on the actual achievement, you could have auto-population of achievement levels + scores depending on the achievement from the employee. 

Example: 

A <metric-lookup-table-target-auto-population> with percentages of 25, 50, 75, 100, 125. Each percentage mapped to a rating.

Target Baseline that would calculate percentages and populate them on the Metric Lookup Table.

Target Baseline=1000

  • Target Level 250 - Score 1
  • Target Level 500 - Score 2
  • Target Level 750 - Score 3
  • Target Level 1000 - Score 4
  • Target Level 1250 - Score 5 

Actual Achievement of the employee. If 750 would be a Goal rating of 3, if 1000 a rating of 4, if 1125, a rating of 4.5 and so on.

Jordi

entry.title: Re: SAP Course not available - Simplify Integration with...
entry.content:
Hi @MichaelSeydler 

The earlier SAP course has been retired. SAP now offers a more comprehensive “SAP Integration Suite” course covering integration suite fundamentals, iFlow design, adapters, security, API management, and event-driven integration.

This course is available online with live and recorded sessions, offering a practical, hands-on approach to SAP integration on the Business Technology Platform.

You can find more details and if you desire enroll for the courses via the following:

SAP’s official training platform: SAP Integration Suite CLD900

Practical integration courses with exercises: Practical SAP Integration Suite

I hope this provides the desired insights. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

falls bekannt, z.B. "der produzierenden Industrie" oder "im Bereich Logistik und Supply
Chain"] und bin überzeugt, dass meine einzigartige Kombination aus tiefgreifender
operativer Expertise, strategischem Denken und nachweislichen Erfolgen in der
Prozessoptimierung und digitalen Transformation einen wertvollen Beitrag zu Ihren
ambitionierten Zielen leisten kann.
Mein Profil entspricht keinem traditionellen Akademiker, sondern dem eines Logikers,
Taktikers und Strategen , der darauf spezialisiert ist, komplexe
Wertschöpfungsketten zu durchdringen und die Brücke zwischen strategischen

erfasse praktische Anforderungen präzise, übersetze sie in Konzepte und befähige
Spezialisten zur Umsetzung. Meine Qualifikationen als Industriemeister (IHK) und
Logistikmeister (IHK) untermauern meine umfassende praktische Erfahrung und
statten mich mit einem praxisorientierten Ansatz zur Problemlösung und
Implementierung aus.
Meine Expertise – Beitrag zu innovativen Lösungen:
Als treibende Kraft bei der BMW AG habe ich maßgeblich zur digitalen Transformation und
operativen Exzellenz beigetragen. Meine Expertise in der SAP-Bestandsführung und
Logistikautomatisierung, basierend auf über 17 Jahren praktischer
SAP-Anwendungserfahrung (davon 6 Jahre als Key User Vertreter für 3 Werke), führte zu
messbaren Verbesserungen:
Ich initiierte und leitete die Steigerung der SAP-Bestandsgenauigkeit von 74% auf
beeindruckende 98% für 24.000 Sachnummern in drei Werken. Dies erreichte ich durch die
Implementierung fortschrittlicher E-Kanban- und Scan-Systeme, einschließlich robotischer

entry.title: Re: FUE consumption highly increased
entry.content:
Here is an update on this topic for anyone who may find it useful:

  • SAP's Response: We received a response from SAP regarding the recent changes. While they explained the reasoning behind them, they did not provide a solution for being notified in advance. SAP stated:

    "With the release of the latest ruleset v1.69, three (3) authorization objects have been upgraded to a higher use type (from Core to Advanced). These changes are the result of a very thorough analysis of the underlying business processes and are fully aligned with the descriptions provided in the Software Use Rights and Service Description Guide."

  • Our Workaround for Official Updates: To stay informed, we are now regularly monitoring SAP Note 3113382 for any relevant updates.

  • Our Proactive Monitoring Solution: We have also implemented a custom solution to detect changes internally. We have scheduled the report SLIM_USER_CLF_HELP to run weekly. A custom program then compares the last two results to identify any differences in our Full Usage Equivalent (FUE) consumption.

entry.title: Re: target range of coverage is 0 for 1st period in dynam...
entry.content:
Your first period is defined as 30 days, and the system is currently in August 2025. If there are no PIRs or other requirements within August, the system calculates average daily requirement = 0. Since TROC = average daily requirement × target coverage, it results in 0 × 3 = 0.

You've set Number of Periods = 1 for the first coverage range. That means SAP only applies the target coverage of 3 to the first 30-day period. The second and rest-of-horizon periods are effectively ignored because:

  • Second period has “Number of Periods = 0”
  • Rest-of-horizon has all zeros

Setting Max = 0 disables the creation of safety stock even if the target is unmet. So even if the system calculates a shortfall, it won’t generate additional stock to meet the target.

To make the system consider TROC = 3 in MD04 for the first month:

  • Add a small PIR in August 2025 (e.g., 1 unit on any date)
  • Run MRP (MD01 or MD02) to refresh the planning file
  • Optionally, set Max > 0 in OMIA to allow safety stock creation
  • Confirm that PIRs are in version “00” and are active

entry.title: Re: Issue in setting up roles for "Integration Suite Appl...
entry.content:
Hi @AashisKumar_Chittawat92 

The user id already in use error occurs if your user or email is linked to another account or trial. Additionally, access issues also commonly arises when:

Your role collections especially Integration Provisioner are not fully or correctly assigned.

If your permissions propagation and provisioning take time.

Also note that browser cache or session issues block correct access.

Here is what I suggest:

First, verify your role assignment under your BTP subaccount security settings.

Then clear browser cache or try a different browser.

Thereafter, logout and log back in to refresh permissions.

If you are reusing an existing SAP user or email, please ensure no conflicts exist.

Finally, consider creating a new BTP trial account if issues persist.

I hope this provides the desired insights. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Plant to Storage location conversion process steps
entry.content:
Below are the Organizational Structure Impacts

Below are the Procure-To-Pay impacts

  • You can no longer create POs directly to the service center. Instead, POs will be created to the parent plant, and goods will be received into the storage location.
  • GR will now be posted to the storage location under the parent plant. You lose the ability to post GRs directly to a separate valuation area.
  • Invoices will be matched against POs created for the parent plant. Any cost center or internal order assignments must be handled at the parent plant level.
  • You’ll need to use storage location-to-storage location transfers (within the same plant). No more plant-to-plant stock transport orders, which may affect intercompany or interplant logistics.
  • If your service center had different valuation prices, this will be lost. All stock in the storage location will inherit the valuation of the parent plant.
  • Reports that previously segmented by plant will need to be adjusted to filter by storage location. Cost tracking may become less granular unless redesigned.

Below are the recommended approach before you convert

  • Review open POs, PRs, and stock in the service center plant.
  • Close or transfer any open transactions before deactivating the plant.
  • Update master data: material master, vendor master, purchasing info records.
  • Communicate with finance and logistics teams to align on valuation and reporting changes.
  • Consider creating a dedicated cost center for the storage location to retain visibility.

entry.title: Re: COR3 - Target Qty and Cost calculation
entry.content:
Since your system doesn't maintain WRTTP = '05' records (Target values), you'll need to derive target quantity and cost dynamically using planned data and actual output quantity (if available). Here's how you can approach it.

When actual quantity and cost are missing, SAP typically calculates target values using:

Planned Quantity / Planned Output Quantity × Actual Output Quantity

If actual output quantity is missing, you can default to planned output quantity or use a proxy like confirmed quantity or delivered quantity.

You can consider the below tables

In your CDS view, you can:

  • Join KEKO → CKIS to get planned quantities and costs per component.
  • Use KEKO.KLVAR and KEKO.KADAT to filter by costing variant and date.
  • Calculate Target Quantity - TargetQty = CKIS.MENGE / KEKO.KSTKL * <ActualOutputQty or PlannedOutputQty>
  • Calculate Target Cost: - TargetCost = TargetQty × CKIS.EINPREIS
  • If actual output quantity is missing, fallback to KEKO.KSTKL (costing lot size).

Hi @jameswood32 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through some options.

To enable you build a scalable, real-time social media app on SAP, I suggest you consider the following options:

SAP Build Apps with Visual Cloud Functions offers you the option for fast backend and frontend development with low-code tools tailored to social media features like posts and comments.

The SAP HANA Database gives you real-time processing of user interactions and analytics, supporting high throughput and complex data queries.

With the SAP Business Technology Platform your cloud infrastructure, API management, event-driven messaging and integration capabilities which are essential for real-time and scalable apps is also provided available on the platform.

For best Practices I suggest you make use of event-driven architecture, microservices, and SAP Cloud Identity for security.

entry.title: Re: Does SAC's bar graph have a grouping function?
entry.content:
Hi @tsuuuu 

Thank you for your question.

Please note that in SAP Analytics Cloud bar charts, grouping multiple measures under a single dimension is straightforward by assigning measures and dimensions appropriately. However, controlling bar spacing, narrowing spacing for same dimension groups or widening it when dimension changes is not directly configurable via standard options.

There are workarounds you can consider and these include using break grouping to influence order/grouping, adjusting story layout size, or employing scripting in analytic applications for advanced customization. Alternatively, you should consider using in-cell charts for more flexible bar visualizations.

I hope this provides the desired insights. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Virtual Card Payment Setup
entry.content:
Hello @Monali 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the process and setup for using Virtual Card as a vendor payment method without SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity (MBC) or Concur Invoice are outlined below

End-to-End Workflows

  • The standards procure-to-pay process involves: PO, goods receipt, and invoice verification.
  • Virtual Card payments are processed outside SAP through your bank or virtual card provider platform, as there is no direct bank integration (MBC).
  • Payment advice or instructions are created either manually or through SAP payment media files and sent to the card provider.
  • Vendor payments are entered into SAP either manually or through payment proposals associated with virtual card transactions.
  • Bank statement processing helps reconcile payments.

Configuration Steps

  • Activate the virtual card payment option in the Manage Payment Methods for Vendors app.
  • Maintain vendors that use virtual cards as their payment method.
  • Set up payment medium formats that match your provider's requirements if file exchange is used.
  • Use the Schedule Payment Runs app for payment proposals, including virtual card payments.

Important Notes

  • Without MBC, payment execution and reconciliation involve manual or semi-automated procedures
  • Working closely with your virtual card provider helps ensure everything is properly formatted and reconciled, making the process smoother for you.

Helpful SAP Documentations references

  • SAP Help: Payment Methods in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP Help: Virtual Card Payment Process in SAP S/4HANA Cloud 

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Laundry Service Process
entry.content:
Hi @Swaroop_Nayak 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through it.

Based on the information you provided, To enable you to track dirty clothes sent from Plant A to Plant B, handle production cleaning and return clean clothes with proper FI postings, I suggest you consider this SAP supported approach:

Use Intercompany Stock Transport Orders for sending dirty clothes from Plant A to B and returning cleaned clothes.

Capture the cleaning process using Production Orders at Plant B to track the transformation.

Implement Intercompany Service Billing (SD billing) for charging Plant A for cleaning services.

Ensure material masters differentiate dirty vs. clean clothes for inventory management.

Leverage SAP FI for automated postings reflecting intercompany stock movements and billing.

This approach integrates MM, PP, SD, and FI to provide full traceability, inventory control, and financial accounting across your company codes. You can consult the following link for more details.

Intercompany Business Processing

 

I hope this provides the desired insights. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Chris

entry.title: Re: GRC FireFighter error password change
entry.content:
Hello @mritscher77 

The FireFighter password change problem results from the login/password_change_waittime parameter, which limits password changes to once daily.

To enable multiple FireFighter sessions per day without errors:

  • Reduce or disable the password_change_waittime setting if your security policy permits.
  • Use Service User-type FireFighter IDs, which bypass password expiration issues as per SAP KBA1702439.
  • Ensure proper authorisations are in place for FireFighter ID management.

This is the most effective method to securely enable repeated FireFighter usage within a single day.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Dive into the future of SAP Universal ID and understand the changes underway
entry.content:
As valued members of our Community, we’d like to share upcoming changes to SAP Universal ID (UID). It is important that you have all the details to make the transition as simple as possible.

SAP is updating its SAP Universal ID framework to simplify user experiences and improve security. The key change is that the UID will no longer serve as an identity provider, meaning it will no longer represent a digital gatekeeper that checks if the person logging in is really who they say they are. Moving forward, users will have to use their e-mail address or user ID (S-/P-user) to log in. Please note that the SAP Universal ID will still be used as a wallet to collect and store user identities, community reputation and learning certificates.

The information below provides you with a view into the current state of SAP Universal ID, the upcoming changes, benefits of this evolution, and the impact on you.  

If you have any issues during the migration and this article doesn’t address them, our SAP support can help.

What is SAP Universal ID?

SAP Universal ID (UID) was created to serve as a unified personal account or wallet across all SAP systems, managing and linking various user identities such as S-/P-users. This consolidation ensured that learning certificates, awards, and community reputation are retained lifelong, regardless of organizational changes.

What´s changing and what does this mean to you?

As mentioned above, SAP Universal ID will no longer serve as an identity provider. Instead, users will be authenticated through the SAP standard authentication mechanism (SAP IAS).

This change in the authentication approach requires a user password migration for all users of SAP Universal ID. For most users, those with only one user identity (S-/P-users) linked in SAP Universal ID, the password migration will happen automatically. No action is required from those users. They will continue to log in using their email address and the password they are accustomed to.

Users with more than one user identity (S-/P-users) linked in SAP Universal ID will be guided through a step-by-step process to set new password or confirm existing passwords. This will occur during the migration period, that takes place from August 25th till September 29th, 2025.

The SAP Universal ID account will remain active, allowing users to keep linking and managing their user identities in the SAP UID Account Manager. Another benefit of the UID Password Migration initiative for end users is that they lay the foundation for the future introduction of 'Remember me' functionality. Although the enablement timeline cannot be confirmed at this stage, technical preparations are underway, and we will communicate once the feature becomes available.

From September 29th, users will login with their e-mail address or user identity with the associated password. Single sign-on with SAP Universal ID will not be possible anymore. Users who haven’t gone through the password migration procedure during the mentioned period, will need to log in with any of their S-/P-user ID (or the email address associated to it) and a respective password, that was initially set during user creation. In case the password is forgotten, the “forgot password” link can be used for reset. Passwords for the remaining users can be subsequently reset once logged in to the SAP Account Manager.

Why Is SAP Making This Change? 

This change is part of SAP’s broader identity renovation strategy. As SAP continues to evolve its identity and management solutions, the transition to identity renovation represents a new chapter in digital identity consolidation and management. While SAP Universal ID remains a pivotal part of this strategy, the shift towards SAP IAS sessions highlights the dynamic nature of enterprise technology. For customers and partners understanding and adapting to these changes will ensure optimized digital interactions within the SAP ecosystem. 

You can learn more about it in the Bring Your Own Identity: SAP's Strategic Transformation of Identity and Authentication Management blog post.

Detailed User Guide

This guide shows the single steps, you will be asked to go through to set or confirm your passwords during the UID password migration. Please note, that these steps will be required only from users with more than one user identity (S/P-user) linked in their SAP Universal ID. If you belong to the majority users, that have only one user identity (just one either S- or P-user) linked to their UID, the migration will happen automatically in the background and no action will be needed from you.

1. Once you log in, we will ask you to set new passwords to the user identities, that are linked in your SAP Universal ID. You have also the option to choose “remind me later”. In that case, we will ask you again the next time you log in. Please keep in mind, that you should fulfill these steps until September 29th.

2. In the next screen, you will see all your linked user identities. You can either keep and confirm current password, choose to use the UID password or set a completely new password. You need to choose one of the options for each linked user identity. Once done, click on “confirm”.

3. To confirm your choices, we will ask you for your current SAP Universal ID password:

4. You will see a summary of your choices, once you confirmed with your UID password:

After setting successfully your passwords, you will be able to log in with your e-mail address or S-/P-user ID with the associated password.

Further Resources

Read our News article to know more about SAP’s Strategic Transformation of Identity and Authentication Management.  If you have any issues during the migration and this article didn’t address them, our SAP support can help.

entry.title: Re: Using SuccessFactors OAuth2.0 in SAP ECC system
entry.content:
Hi @ramanareddymoola @cyanezde 

I hope this can still help @ramanareddymoola 

To integrate SuccessFactors OData API with SAP ECC using OAuth 2.0, I suggest you follow these key steps:

First, register your ECC as an OAuth client in SuccessFactors with required scopes.

Then ensure you configure an OAuth 2.0 HTTP destination in SM59 with client ID/secret.

In your ABAP program, request an OAuth token from SuccessFactors token endpoint. This is typically via a standard POST with client credentials.

Thereafter, use the received token as a Bearer token in the Authorization header while calling OData API.

Finally, note that signed XML payloads are generally not needed for OAuth 2.0 client credentials flow. These apply more to SAML or advanced scenarios. Kindly refer to the following link for more details.

SAP SuccessFactors Integration with SAP ERP

I hope this provides the desired insights. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Configurar impresión de estados financieros en SAP Ve...
entry.content:
Hola @Loscoy 

In SAP ECC 7.4 (SAP ERP 6.0 EHP7 on NetWeaver 7.4), financial statements are set up and printed directly in FI using Financial Statement Versions (FSV).

Main Steps

  1. Define the Financial Statement Version (FSV)
    • Transaction: OB58
    • Create or copy a standard version (e.g. 001).
    • Assign G/L accounts to nodes for Assets, Liabilities, and P&L.
  1. Assign the FSV to the company code.e
  • Transaction: OB61
  1. Generate Standard Financial Reportss
  • S_ALR_87012284 → Balance Sheet
  • S_ALR_87012282 → Profit and Loss Statement
  • S_ALR_87012283 → Income Statement by Function
  • S_ALR_87012285 → Cash Flow (basic version)

These reports allow direct printing and export to Excel.

  1. Additional Options
  • For more advanced layouts, use Report Painter/Report Writer (transactions GRR1, GR55).
  • For statutory reporting, FI-SL (Special Ledger) can also be used if active in your system.

Recommendation

Although your version is outdated, the FSV and ALR reports setup remains functional and stable. For better flexibility, you might also consider switching to Report Painter as a best practice.

Reference: SAP Help – Financial Statement Versions (FSV)

Managing Financial Statement Versions-SAP Learning

With kind regards

Chujma

entry.title: Re: target range of coverage is 0 for 1st period in dynam...
entry.content:
Your coverage profile defines monthly period of 30 days, starting from the current date. If your PIRs are dated late in August (e.g., August 31), and your system clock is already at August 22, the system may not count those PIRs as part of the first period. SAP calculates average daily requirement based on requirements within the current coverage period, not just the calendar month.

You’ve set Number of Periods = 3 for the first coverage range, which is unusual. This means SAP will average requirements over 3 periods (i.e., 90 days) but apply the target coverage of 3 days only to the first 30-day period. This can dilute the average daily requirement if future periods have low or no demand.

If your PIRs are generated via forecast (e.g., MD61 with forecast model), ensure they are in version “00” and active. Forecast versions other than “00” are ignored by MRP unless explicitly configured.

To set things right and to get the TROC calculation working as expected, try the below approach

Set Number of Periods = 1 in Coverage Range. This ensures SAP calculates average daily requirement based only on the first 30-day period, which aligns with your target coverage of 3 days.

Ensure PIRs exist within the first period. Add a PIR for August 22–30, not August 31. Even a small quantity (e.g., 1 unit) will trigger the calculation.

Run MRP again using MD01 or MD02 to refresh the planning file. Check MD04 after the run to see updated TROC.

So considering the above points, the below setup should work

ST113 – Journey to unified extensibility in SAP Business Suite and cloud ERP
Explore the strategy for extensibility across SAP Business Suite and cloud ERP. Learn why AI-driven development with the SAP Build solution including ABAP Cloud is key, and how the planned harmonization will make it easier to build extensions and support the clean core. Furthermore, learn about opportunities for partners to extend SAP solutions.
Speakers: Boris Gebhardt (SAP), Khaled Musilhy (SAP), tbd

🗺️ Roadmap Sessions (25 minutes)

AD808 – SAP Build: ABAP Cloud road map
See our upcoming innovations for the ABAP Cloud development model including Joule and the Business Data Cloud integration in context and get updates on the roadmap ahead.
Speakers: Boris Gebhardt (SAP)

DT814 – Extensibility innovations road map for SAP Business Suite and cloud ERP
Explore upcoming extensibility innovations for SAP Business Suite and cloud ERP. Discover road maps for suite extensibility, harmonization, and partner enablement for commercial use cases. Learn more about upcoming innovations for AI-driven extensibility with the SAP Build solution including ABAP Cloud to support your clean core strategy.
Speakers: Oren Shatil (SAP), Boris Gebhardt (SAP), External Speaker

🔍Deep Dives (45 minutes)

AD104 – Boost your  ABAP development with Joule for developers  | also available virtually as AD104v
In this deep dive session you will learn all aspects of the ABAP AI strategy, from accelerating your ABAP development, over developing custom AI scenarios, up to using Joule to transform your ABAP code.
Speakers: Simona Marincei (SAP), Olga Dolinskaja (SAP)

AD105 – Introduction to ABAP Cloud and how to get started 
ABAP Cloud is the new way of developing ABAP—fully cloud-enabled and driven by AI. It combines cloud technologies with a clear separation of SAP and custom code, and in this way revolutionizes ABAP development. Grasp the major concepts of ABAP Cloud and learn how you can upskill. Also learn about Bosch Digital’s journey to ABAP Cloud and clean core.
Speakers: Carine Tchoutouo Djomo (SAP), External Speaker

AD201 – Explore ABAP Cloud in SAP Build - what's in for ABAP developers?   
In this deep dive we will highlight the importance of our strategic approach of integrating ABAP Cloud in SAP Build. Learn how you can benefit from this for Fiori App development and how the graphical modeler helps you to create ABAP CDS models conveniently. Finally, get insights into the future direction.
Speakers: Dr. Anne Keller (SAP), Katja Zoch (SAP)

DT200 – Unravel the mysteries of Clean Core extensions in Cloud ERP Private 
Learn about the new, enhanced clean core extensibility concept in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. Learn about tools like ABAP Test Cockpit and RISE Dashboard, as well as guidance and best practices that help you to measure, govern, re-factor and develop your custom extensions in a clean core compliant, upgrade stable and cloud-ready way.
Speakers: Olga Dolinskaja (SAP), Markus Goebel (SAP)

DT201 – Extensibility with ABAP Cloud and AI in SAP Cloud ERP
Learn about the on-stack key user and developer tools in the ABAP Cloud development model, now enhanced with generative AI. See how you can extend standard SAP applications and manage your custom apps directly in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Get insights into latest innovations for transactional, analytical, and integration use cases, such as the extensibility AI Assistant, editable tree-views, custom queries for analytical SAP Fiori apps, ABAP SQL services and more.
Speakers: Carine Tchoutouo Djomo (SAP), Oren Shatil (SAP)

🛠️ Hands-On Workshops (2 hours)

AD162 – Explore Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities    
Learn how to develop a RAP business object while exploring Joule's ABAP AI capabilities
Speakers: Sebastian Baskovich (SAP), Thomas Alexander Ritter (SAP), Dr. Anne Keller (SAP), Simona Marincei (SAP)

AD163 – Fusion Development with ABAP Cloud in SAP Build
In this session we will practice fusion development of ABAP Cloud in SAP Build by creating an ABAP Cloud project from the SAP Build lobby to develop a RAP BO including a Fiori application on top.
Speakers: Ingo Braüninger (SAP), Sebastian Baskovich (SAP), Anne Keller (SAP), Katja Zoch (SAP)

AD164 – Get started with ABAP Cloud for classic ABAP developers    
Familiar with classic ABAP development? Join us to learn how similar development works with ABAP Cloud development model using the ABAP RESTful application programming model (RAP). ABAP Cloud is the comprehensive model for building cloud-ready business apps, services, and extensions that follow clean core principles by default – on SAP BTP and SAP S/4HANA, both in the cloud and on-premise.
Speakers: Volker Drees (SAP), Carine Tchoutouo Djomo (SAP), Boris Gebhardt (SAP), Jürgen Reidl (SAP)

DT260 – Modernize classic extensions to clean core in Cloud ERP Private    
In this session you will practice a clean core extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. You will learn how to govern clean core development using the ABAP Test Cockpit, and how to use ABAP Cloud and clean core extensibility principles to modernize your custom on-stack extensions.
Speakers: Ingo Bräuninger (SAP), Olga Dolinskaja (SAP), Thomas Fiedler (SAP), Markus Goebel (SAP)

DT261 – Build on-stack extensions with ABAP Cloud in Cloud ERP Public
Join us to discover how to build extensions, applications, and services with the ABAP Cloud development model, using the ABAP RESTful application programming model and generative AI. You will learn how to extend standard SAP applications, consume public SAP APIs, and build new apps and services from scratch. Get practical insights through exercises and take the opportunity to ask your questions.
Speakers: Ingo Bräuninger (SAP), Carine Tchoutouo Djomo (SAP), Volker Drees (SAP), Steffen Mattes (SAP)

DT266 – Troubleshoot and Optimize ABAP Cloud Extensions in Cloud ERP 
Ensuring optimal performance and stability of your ABAP Cloud-based extensions is crucial to long-term success. Learn advanced techniques and best practices for troubleshooting and optimizing custom code in the Cloud ERP. Use powerful tools like ABAP Cross Trace to get deep insights into execution flows and resource consumption.
Speakers: Steffen Mattes (SAP), Juergen Reidl (SAP), Thomas Alexander Ritter (SAP), Thomas Fiedler (SAP)

👋Join Us

I hope this overview gives you even more reasons to join us at one of the SAP TechEd 2025 tour stops in Berlin (DE), Louisville (US), Sydney (AU), Bangalore (IN), Birmingham (UK), or Hamburg (DE) – or attend online, free of charge!

We look forward to meeting and interacting with you! 🤝  In the meantime, you can watch the replays of last year's events: ABAP Cloud at SAP TechEd Virtual 2024 and ABAP Cloud at SAP's Devtoberfest in 2024.

Stay tuned – and see you there!

entry.title: Re: GR and stock management for WIP half cooked material...
entry.content:
Try with the below approach

Create a dedicated storage location to represent the staging area. After the first operation, post a transfer from the shop floor to this WIP location using MB1B (Movement Type 311) or MIGO. This gives you visibility of WIP stock in MMBE or Stock Overview.

Continue using PP03 for the second operation to trigger the Purchase Requisition and Purchase Order. Ensure the component assignment is correct so that the WIP material is linked to the external operation.

In the Material Master (QM View), set up QM control key for external processing. In PO, set Inspection Type 01 or 04 depending on your setup. Upon GR, SAP will generate an inspection lot which allows quality check before consumption.

Treat the WIP material as a subcontracting component in the PO. Use ME2O to monitor subcontracting stock. This way, SAP tracks the WIP material sent to the vendor and expects it back post-processing.

In the routing, ensure the final operation consumes the WIP material. This prevents premature consumption and aligns with your inspection logic.

Below is the Process flow summary

entry.title: Re: Issue with Subsequent Delivery Free of Charge in Adva...
entry.content:
In your case, the SD step fails with Copying Requirement 304, which checks for a valid Reason for Rejection. If the item is billing-relevant and the rejection reason is missing or greyed out, SAP won’t allow the SD order to copy the item. So, Billing Relevance + Missing Rejection Reason = Copying Failure.

Coming to your issue, what is your item category REN settings for "Billing Relevance" and Screen Sequence Group?

Go to vov7, select the item category used for your returns and check both the above. Make a note of those. Go to VFBS, enter program SAPMV45A and Screen Group (in standard, this is N), so that, you’ll see a list of function codes and screen sequences.

Look for the function code related to item detail (usually UER2 or UEB2). Double-click to open the screen layout. In the screen layout, locate the field for Reason for Rejection (technical name: VBAP-ABGRU). Check what status is set there. According to your post, I presume, it is set to either Display or Hidden or Suppress which should be changed to Optional. So, once you done this, assign a valid Reason for Rejection before triggering the SD step. This combination ensures SAP recognizes the item as not billable, and allows the SD order to be created successfully.

entry.title: Re: Query on Advanced Return Management for Service and N...
entry.content:
The error “Invalid Movement Type 657” occurs because:

  • Movement Type 657 is used for returns to stock in ARM.
  • Service items and NLAG items do not involve inventory postings.
  • SAP tries to post a goods movement for an item that doesn’t have stock, which leads to the error.

To answer your question whether you can use ARM for Service and NLAG Items?, the answer is NO. SAP does not support ARM flows for Service items (item category TATX) and NLAG items (non-stock items, typically item category KLN or similar)

If you need to process returns for these items, consider going with Standard Return Order (without ARM). Create a manual return order referencing the original invoice. Skip the ARM-specific flows like automatic delivery or credit memo.

Finally, if your business requires ARM-like tracking for services or NLAGs, you could create a custom item category that bypasses movement type 657. Use user exits or BAdIs to suppress inventory logic. But this requires development effort and careful testing.

entry.title: Re: Functional Area not found in TCode GR55
entry.content:
Functional Area 1000 is present in GRR2 because it's included in the report definition. However, as I said already, GR55 only displays functional areas with posted data—so if no transactions have been made using 1000, 2000, or 3000, they won’t appear in GR55 even though they’re defined in OKBD or GRR2.

Functional areas are typically assigned in the Cost Center Master (KS03), not directly in KE53. To trace them via KE53:

  • Go to KE53 → Environment → Assignments to find linked cost centers.
  • Then check those cost centers in KS03 to see which functional area is assigned.

To verify visibility in GR55, try posting a test transaction using FB50 or KB21N with one of the functional areas. After posting, re-run GR55 to confirm if it appears.

Also, ensure the report group used in GR55 includes functional area as a selection/output field—check this in GRR1.

entry.title: Mexico Union Dues
entry.content:
​In Mexico, union dues are payments made by workers to their labor unions to support union activities, administration, and collective bargaining efforts. These dues are governed by Mexico’s Federal Labor Law (Ley Federal del Trabajo) and are typically outlined in the union’s statutes and collective bargaining agreements

​

  • The amount due is set by the union itself and approved by its members; there’s no fixed national rate.
  • Dues are deducted directly from employees’ paychecks by the employer and transferred to the union

The Union fund is used often for union operations, legal representation, training, and negotiation efforts.

entry.title: Re: user-defined fields blocked/read only SAP BO Purchase...
entry.content:
Hello @abasilis 

Thanks for sharing the screenshot. The behaviour is due to the Financial Limited license, which allows viewing Purchase Orders but does not support searching by User-Defined Fields in the Find window. That’s why the fields appear read-only.

Options

  • Assign a Professional or Logistics Limited license if a UDF search is required or use a custom query via Query Manager to filter by UDF values.

This is a license limitation rather than a system error.

License Guide for SAP Business One 10.0

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: SAP BTP ABAP Environment - Release 2508
entry.content:
SAP BTP ABAP Environment - Release 2508

With the launch of the new release 2508, this blog post delivers an in-depth overview of the newest features and improvements. The release has been available since August 16th, replacing the previous 2505 release. The highlights of the current release include: Support of CDS Table Entities as active persistence in RAP, SAP Fiori-based Multi-Dimensional Reporting or the new software delivery option for partners the "Add-On Product". 

The list of all new features can be found on the What's New for SAP BTP ABAP Environment page

All new AI features are summarized here.

ABAP Development Tools (ADT)

  • Creation of Behavior Definition for CDS Table Entities (see Table Entities and Creating Data Definitions)
  • New Icons for Fiori User Interface Editors (details)
  • Extensions to the Class and Interface: C1 Consistency and Compatibility Checks, the ATC checks API Release: Consistency of Released APIs and API Release: Compatibility of Released APIs now check for consistency and compatibility about BDEF-derived types in released classes and interfaces
  • ADT Debugger Comparison Tool for Internal Tables (details)
  • Enrichment in the Element Information Popup, you can now search for substrings within the structured display of the Element Information popup (see Editing ABAP Source Code and Analyzing CDS Objects)
  • Learning from the Key Bindings Toolbar and Highlighting Ghost Text at Keyword Completion In-Line (see Concepts: Keyword Completion and Tasks: Keyword Completion)
  • Display of Copyright Statement for ABAP Development Objects in Properties View
  • HTTP-based ADT Links for Form-Based Objects, until now, the HTTP-link support was available only for the source-code-based ABAP objects 
  • RAP Business Objects Test Double Framework: Auto-Fill CID Support for Modify EML Statement (details)
  • Working with Forms, you can create form templates using Adobe LiveCycle Designer directly in ABAP development tools for Eclipse. Form Templates can be retrieved during runtime via the class CL_FP_FORM_READER (details)
  • Working with Electronic Document Consistency Checks, you can now create and modify the consistency checks you want to perform on your business documents
  • Working with Electronic Document Consistency Representation Types, you can create and modify representation types for your business documents based on their source location. Configure these representation types within the Electronic Document Consistency framework to ensure consistency

Core Data Services

  • New CDS Views in Business Event Logging: C_BUEVLGEVTFULLPYLDJSONDEX_2: Business Event Data v2, C_BUSEVTLOGACTIVITYDEX: Business Event Activity,  C_BUSEVTLOGEVENTDEX_3: Business Event Header Data (v3)
  • Deprecated CDS Views in Business Event Logging: C_BUSEVTLOGEVENTDEX_2 (Business Event Header Data (v2) Use the following successor: C_BUSEVTLOGEVENTDEX_3 and C_BUEVLGEVTFULLPAYLOADJSONDEX (Business Event Data): Use the following successor: C_BUEVLGEVTFULLPYLDJSONDEX_2
  • CDS Hierarchy Generation Wizard, the wizard will derive potential hierarchy nodes already from the start (on the master data view) and guide you through the creation process

RAP

  • Collaborative Draft, you can now add collaborative capabilities to your business object. The collaborative draft allows multiple users to work concurrently on the same draft instance (details)
  • Cross-BO Transactional Enablement, cross-BO scenarios can now be transactionally enabled by defining a cross-BO context for the respective BDEFs (see RAP-Operations for Associations and RAP-with Cross Associations and RAP-AssocImplType)
  • RAP Factory Actions, they now return the http status 201 instead of 200 in case of a successful OData V4 response

SAP Fiori

  • Fiori-Based Multi-Dimensional Reporting – Cloud-Compliant, you need to quickly build an analytical Fiori application, but simple list reporting doesn’t satisfy your needs? Instead, you already built an analytical model with the new embedded analytics capabilities of the developer extensibility and now want to unleash its full potential? In that case, we have the right solution for you: Without writing a single line of additional code, you can simply expose your model in a full-fledged analytical application with a modern Fiori-based UI and real multi-dimensional “slicing & dicing” capabilities
  • Fiori-Based Multi-Report Applications, you need to quickly build an analytical Fiori application, that puts multiple analytical queries into one context in a single UI? All you need to do is to provide the queries, bundle them in an InA Service and you are good to just start the brand new "Review Booklet Application" wizard to generate the application. Afterwards, you can refine the configuration of your Review Booklet in an easy to use Fiori UI
  • Fiori UIs for Communication Management Change History, it is now possible to view the communication management change history in Fiori UIs
  • Change Document Reuse UI, you can embed a reuse UI in your RAP OData V4 Fiori application (details)

Business Configuration 

  • Reduce Footprint with the existing RAP generator for business configuration maintenance objects, you can easily generate all development objects that are required for a configuration object. Since the number of objects is still quite large, optimizations in the RAP programming model have been implemented that reduce the number of required development objects and make them easier for a developer to manage 

Security

  • Business User Authentication, option for configuring secondary signing certificates, currently only basic authentication is supported as authentication for SMTP outbound communication. With this feature, also the OAuth Client Credential Grant will be supported

Business Events

  • Activate Business Event Logging, with this release, there are changes to the behavior of the configuration object. The option to select the logging of all data has been removed. By default, when you enable logging of data, all business event data will be recorded (details)
  • View Object Relationships, with this feature, you can view inbound and outbound relationships for logged objects in business event logging. You can also navigate across object components (details)
  • Log RAP-based C1 events, this feature enables the logging of C1-released, RAP-based events for local consumption (details)
  • Grouping Events as Activities, with this release, events of the same type and object occurring in the same session are grouped as activities. Sequences in the application Display Business Events by Objects are displayed according to activities. A new CDS view is also released to retrieve activity details. An activity is an action performed by a user or the system that initiates an event in the system (details) 
  • Expose Extensibility Status in Open Resource Discovery Document for Business Events, the Open Resource Discovery document for business events now exposes the extensibility status (details)
  • Success Log For Processed Events, it is now possible to configure a log for successfully processed events
  • Source Event Filter, you can now restrict the sending of events by defining filters for event topics. These filters can now also be created directly for event payload properties

Integration

  • Code Snippet in SOAP Service Consumption Model changed, the updated service consumption model improves the instantiation of consumer proxies and optimizes receiver determination through logical ports (details)

  • You can build and manage your own application interfaces in ABAP development tools for Eclipse (ADT) with the SAP Application Interface Framework (AIF). Due to the lack of ADT for AIF, the development objects for asynchronous integrations (event consumption model and asynchronous SOAP services) currently generate their corresponding AIF interfaces with default monitoring settings automatically. With new AIF development capabilities in ADT, these AIF interfaces can be customized. Custom AIF interfaces can also be created, for monitoring the background processing framework (bgPF) in ABAP Cloud, for example
  • The ABAP HTTP client and server now support server-sent events (SSE). Which allows a server to send parts of the body of the response to the client without the client having to actively request them. After being sent by the server, the client can fetch them as they become available (details)

Data Integration

  • Outbound SQL via CDS External Entities, the ADT generation wizard allows you to develop outbound SQL scenarios more efficiently by generating the required CDS external entities based on an imported CSN definition of the remote SQL API
  • SQL Service, INSERT and DELETE on Writable CDS View Entities, in data integration scenarios, users can access data in an ABAP system from an external consumer, using the SQL service and the ODBC driver for ABAP. So far, users can query data in exposed CDS view entities, and this was a read-only scenario, where SELECT statements could be used. Now, the SQL service can also be used to change data in exposed writable CDS view entities using INSERT and DELETE statements. Use cases for INSERT and DELETE in such a data integration scenario include: full replication of data from another system into the ABAP system or bringing data into staging tables that will be later used for your custom ABAP coding (details)

Reuse Services

  • Print Queue Administrator Integration, you can now create and delete print queues directly using APIs without the need to enter the Maintain Print Queues app. You can do so using the communication scenario SAP_COM_0A86 (details)

Background Processing Framework

  • Background processing is very important for business applications. A lot of logic can be executed asynchronously to improve performance. In scenarios where changes of the current LUW are to be communicated remotely, the asynchronous execution is even mandatory to be compliant with the SAP LUW (due to implicit database commits). We want to simplify and improve the background processing by covering all required qualities like: “exactly once”, “in order”, testability and an integration into the ADT cross trace for better supportability (details)

Technical Monitoring

  • SQL Statement Analysis app, with this app, you can analyze the performance and resource consumption of SQL statements within a selectable time range (details)

Lifecycle Management

  • Manage Software Components, the delete dialog for Bring Your Own Git has been modified. The Unregister repository checkbox within the dialog has been moved outside the dialog and changed to a separate Unregister button (see Delete Software Components and Bring Your Own Git)

Custom Code Migration App

  • Redesign of Fiori Space and Page Templates, the Custom Code Migration Fiori app has been split up into two separate tiles. There is now the Analyze Custom Code app for the custom code analysis use case and the Custom Code Migration app for the migration to SAP S/4HANA use case (details)

Landscape Portal

  • Delivery of an Add-On Product, if you have an SAP Partner Edge Build contract, you can now publish a product as an add-on product. This offers a second delivery option for partners as an alternative to the multitenancy SaaS solution. Your product will appear in the SAP Store, where eligible customers can install it in their own SAP BTP ABAP environment system. The Landscape Portal is used for both, to publish add-on products by partners, and to install them by the customers (details)

SAP Fiori Launchpad

  • Manage Launchpad Spaces and Pages: Redesign and Renaming, adapted overview pages to enhance working with spaces and space templates, as well as with pages and page templates. "Predefined" and "SAP-Delivered" were renamed to "Templates" to ensure consistent terminology between these apps (see Manage Launchpad Spaces and Manage Launchpad Pages)
  • New Layout for Launchpad Shell Bar and Menus (see User Menu, Shell and Shel Bar and Working with Notifications)

SAPUI5

  • Referenced SAPUI5 Version, as part of hotfix collection 4 (which is used for the standard upgrade), SAPUI5 version 1.136.4 is used for the administrator’s SAP Fiori launchpad, SAP-delivered Fiori apps, and the custom-built SAP Fiori apps, which are deployed to the ABAP system (see upgrade windows and SAPUI5)
